title-group.article-title: Psychiatric disorders and following risk of chronic kidney disease: a prospective cohort study from UK Biobank

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Psychiatric disorders have been reported to influence many health outcomes, but evidence about their impact on chronic kidney disease (CKD) has not been fully explored, as well as possible mechanisms implicated are still unclear.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Four hundred forty-one thousand eight hundred ninety-three participants from UK Biobank were included in this study. To assess the association between psychiatric disorders mainly including depression, anxiety, stress-related disorders, substance misuse as well as psychotic disorder, and CKD, a Cox regression model using age as the underlying time scale was employed. This approach considers the age progression of participants from the beginning to the end of the study as the elapsed time. Flexible nonparametric smoothing model was conducted to illustrate the temporal patterns. Subgroup analyses were performed by stratification of gender, genetic susceptibility to CKD, age at entry or exit the cohort, follow-up duration, and the number of psychiatric disorders at baseline. Mediation analysis was implemented to evaluate the roles of body mass index (BMI), hypertension, and diabetes.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Compared with individuals without psychiatric disorders, an increased risk of CKD was observed in patients with psychiatric disorders (hazard ratios (HR) = 1.52, 95% confidence intervals (CI): 1.40–1.65, p-value < 0.001). The hazard ratio among psychiatric patients gradually increased, and became significant after about 10 years follow-ups. The HR for patients followed up for 10–12 years was 1.60 (95% CI: 1.34–1.91, p-value < 0.001), and the HR was 1.66 (95% CI: 1.29–2.13, p-value < 0.001) for patients followed up for 12–13 years. Five distinct psychiatric disorders were found to be significantly associated with an increased risk of developing CKD. The highest HR was observed between stress-related disorder and CKD (HR = 1.95, 95%CI: 1.28–2.97, p-value = 0.002). When adjusting genetic susceptibility to CKD, the HR for the association between stress-related disorders and CKD became 1.86 (95%CI: 1.14–3.04, p-value = 0.013). Although these associations were nominally significant, they did not reach statistical significance after applying the Bonferroni multiple corrections, potentially due to the limited sample size. Subgroup analysis revealed that psychiatric patients who are under age 60, with multiple psychiatric morbidities or having been diagnosed with psychiatric disorders for over 10 years may be high-risk populations. Hypertension, BMI and diabetes mediated 49.13% (95% CI: 37.60%-67.08%), 12.11% (95% CI: 8.49%-17.24%) and 3.78% (95% CI: 1.58%-6.52%) of the total effect, respectively.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Psychiatric disorders were associated with a delayed onset of an elevated risk for CKD, this association was only observed in patients with psychiatric disorders for more than 10 years. Our study highlights the significance of lifestyle interventions, routine monitoring of kidney function, early screening for CKD, and personalized management strategies for psychiatric patients as potential approaches to the precise prevention of CKD.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a long-term condition that is growing in prevalence, yet receives limited recognition. According to the statistics from the Global Burden of Disease, approximately one-tenth of the world’s population was affected by CKD, which caused 1.5 million deaths [1, 2]. Due to a lack of symptoms, early-stage CKD is often hard to detect [3]. CKD can progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD), between 2001 and 2019, the number of patients with newly registered ESRD increased by 37.8% in the U.S. [4], leading to significant social and economic burdens [5]. Many people are diagnosed at the end stage, requiring kidney replacement therapy to stay alive, which burdens both patients and the healthcare system [6, 7]. Therefore, identifying risk factors of CKD is crucial in reducing CKD incidence.

Psychiatric disorders may last for a long time and impact many health outcomes throughout life. Psychiatric disorders are not only associated with some neuropsychiatric disorders like dementia [8], Parkinson’s disease [9] and Alzheimer’s disease [10], but also many somatic diseases, for example, hypertension [11], diabetes [12], cardiovascular diseases [13, 14], heart failure [15, 16], autoimmune disease [17], infection [18] and cancer [19]. One study focusing on the disease trajectories following psychiatric disorders found the trajectory from depression to CKD [20]. Patients with CKD or ESRD usually comorbid with more prevalent comorbid psychiatric conditions, which can affect mental health in turn [21]. However, the effects of multiple types of clinically confirmed psychiatric disorders on the following risk of CKD have not been fully explored using longitudinal data, as well as possible mechanisms involved in the association are still unclear.

Using the population-based longitudinal data from the UK Biobank, we assessed the effects of psychiatric disorders, primarily including depression, anxiety, stress-related disorder, substance misuse as well as psychotic disorders on the risk of subsequent CKD. We also evaluated the impact of age, gender, follow-up time, number of psychiatric disorders and genetic predisposition on this association. Mediation analyses were performed to elucidate the possible mechanisms linking psychiatric disorders and CKD.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: This study assessed the association between psychiatric disorders and CKD using data from the UK Biobank cohort study. The UK Biobank is a large population-based prospective cohort study that recruited approximately 500,000 middle-aged (40–69 years) participants from England, Scotland and Wales. Baseline data from the UK Biobank was collected between 2006 and 2010 in 22 research assessment centers across the UK. With the consent of participants, health-related outcomes were obtained periodically from external healthcare providers. Hospital inpatient records were linked to Hospital Episode Statistics (HES) for England, Scottish Morbidity Record for Scotland, and Patient Episode Database for Wales, Nationwide mortality data were derived from the National Health Service (NHS) Digital for England and Wales, as well as NHS Central Register for Scotland [22].

sec.title: Study design
sec.p:
In the present study, among 502,507 participants, we excluded participants based on the following criteria: (1) withdrew their consent form (N = 194); (2) with any congenital CKD proceeding the baseline (N = 8,595); (3) diagnosed CKD before the start of follow-up (90 days after the date of recruitment, N = 2,619); (4) with estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) < 60 mL ·min−1 1.73 m−2 based on eGFRcreate or missing values on eGFRcreate (N = 49,101) at the recruitment between 2006 to 2010; and (5) died before the start of follow up (N = 105). Finally, 441,893 participants were included in the final primary analytic cohort (Fig. 1).Fig. 1
Flowchart of study population. CKD: Chronic kidney disease; QC: Quality control

In order to explore the influence of genetic predisposition on the association between psychiatric disorders and CKD, we derived a genetic cohort by further excluding participants based on the following criteria: (1) non-Caucasian (N = 23,609); (2) did not pass the quality control of genetic data (i.e., with in-consistent self-reported and genetic sex, or high rates of genotype missingness and heterozygosity; N = 105,318); and (3) with first or second level of relatedness (i.e., with the kinship coefficient > 0.0884; N = 15,179) [23]. Finally, 297,787 participants were included in the final genetic analytic cohort. The flowchart representing the selection of study population was shown in Fig. 1. The characteristics of participants with or without psychiatric disorders were presented and compared using t test or chi-squared test, as appropriate.

sec.title: Ascertainment of exposure
sec.p: We retrieved diagnosis information of depression, anxiety, stress-related disorder, substance misuse, and psychotic disorders using ICD-9 and ICD-10 codes from UK Biobank inpatient records (codes were listed in Additional File 1: Supplementary Table S1) [24, 25]. Psychiatric disorders at the baseline were defined as any of 5 diseases as mentioned above. If an individual had received more than one diagnosis of the same psychiatric disorder prior to the baseline, we included the date of the initial diagnosis for each of the five psychiatric disorders in our analyses.

sec.title: Ascertainment of outcomes
sec.p: CKD outcomes were identified as follows: (1) first diagnosis of incident chronic renal failure, initiation of renal replacement therapy, development of renal complications of hypertension or diabetes, glomerular diseases, or other renal structural abnormality after 90 days of the recruitment date (ICD-10 codes were listed in Additional File 1: Supplementary Table S2); (2) presenting with decreased kidney function, defined by urine albumin/creatinine ratio ≥ 30 mg/g, or eGFR < 60 mL ·min−1 1.73 m−2 based on eGFRcreat or eGFRcreat−cys as appropriate [26], at the repeated assessment during follow-up from 2012 to 2013. The timing of event was recorded by the first diagnosis date of CKD incidence, or 31 December 2012, which was the timing for ascertaining incident CKD by abnormal laboratory tests. As the diagnosis of CKD is based on persistent kidney impairment for at least three months, we used a time interval of 90 days from the date of recruitment to define the CKD outcome [26]. The end of follow-up was the date of first CKD diagnosis, the date of death, or the end of follow up (31 August 2021) whichever came first.

sec.title: Ascertainment of covariates
sec.p: Covariates included sex [27], ethnicity [28], education level [29], annual household income level [30], Townsend deprivation index [31], diet including tea intake, vegetable intake, processed meat intake and unprocessed meat [32], physical activity level and body mass index (BMI) [26, 33] collected at baseline, and age, hypertension [34], diabetes [35] and Charlson comorbidity index [36] collected until November 2016. Data fields and questionnaires used to define the covariates were listed in Additional File 1: Supplementary Table S3. Charlson Comorbidity index (CCI) at baseline, an indicative of baseline comorbidity level, was calculated using diagnoses of the UK Biobank inpatient hospital records as described previously (the definition of CCI was described in Additional File 1: Supplementary Table S4), and categorized in 5 classes, 0, 1–2, 3–4 and ≥ 5 [37, 38]. Ethnicity was divided into White, Asian, Black, mixed and others reported by participants. Education level was categorized into one category of A levels /AS levels /O levels /GCSEs / GSEs or equivalent, one category of college or university degree, and one category of other qualifications [39]. Townsend deprivation index was quantified according to the postal code of participants. Annual household income was divided into ultra-high (> ₤100,000), high (₤52,000 to ₤100,000), medium (₤31,000 to ₤51,999), low (₤18,000 to ₤30,999) and ultra-low (< ₤18,000) levels and ultra-low levels. BMI was categorized into obese (≥ 30kg/m2), overweight (25–30 kg/m2), normal (≤ 30kg/m2) and unknown. Physical activity was defined as low level (< 10 h moderate to vigorous physical activities per week), moderate level (10–50 h moderate to vigorous physical activities per week), high level (≥ 50 h moderate to vigorous physical activities per week) [40] and unknown. Deity factors included unprocessed meat intake (classified into < 1, 1–2, > 2 times per week or unknown), processed meat intake (never, < 1, 1, ≥ 2 times per week or unknown), vegetables intake (< 2, 2–3, 3–4, ≥ 4 servings per day or unknown) and tea intake (nondrinker, < 2, 2–3, > 3 cups per day or unknown). The missing value were coded as an “unknown” category for all the categorical variables [32].

sec.title: Polygenetic risk score of CKD
sec.p: Genotyping in the UK Biobank was performed using the UK BiLEVE Axiom™ Array and UK Biobank Axiom array from Affymetrix, and variants were imputed using Haplotype Reference Consortium, as well as merging UK10K and 1000 Genomes phase 3 reference panels. In this study, a recent genome-wide association study of eGFR based on serum creatinine of CKD Genetics (CKDGen) Consortium was used as the base data [41], and the Polygenetic risk score (PRS) was calculated using PLINK 1.9 (details were described in Additional File 1: Supplementary Methods).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The proportional hazard (PH) assumption of the Cox regression model was firstly tested using “cox.zph” function in “survival” package (version 3.5.5). The cumulative incidence curves were plotted for individuals with and without psychiatric disorders to visually assess whether the PH assumption might be violated [42]. To evaluate the effects of psychiatric disorders on the subsequent risk of developing CKD, Cox regression model was employed, utilizing age as the underlying time scale. This approach considers the age progression of participants from the start of the study to the end of the study as time elapsed and could better account for the left-censoring of the participants compared to conventional methods [43]. Model was adjusted for sex (female or male), ethnicity (Asian, Black, mixed, White or other), social economic factors including Townsend deprivation index (in quantile), annual household income (ultralow, low, medium, high, ultrahigh or unknown), the education level (college or university degree, A levels/ AS levels/ O levels/ GCSEs/ CSEs or equivalent, other degree, or unknown), lifestyle factors including physical activity (low, moderate, high levels or unknown), unprocessed meat intake (< 1, 1–2, or 2 times per week or unknown), processed meat intake (never, < 1, 1, ≥ 2 times per week or unknown), vegetable intake (< 2, 2–3, 3–4, ≥ 4 servings per day or unknown),tea intake (nondrinker, < 2, 2–3, > 3 cups per day or unknown), BMI (normal, overweight, obese or unknown), the CCI (0, 1–2, 3–4, or ≥ 5), hypertension and diabetes at baseline (yes or no) or genetic risk of CKD (in tertile).

The separate effects of 5 different psychiatric disorders at baseline (depression, anxiety, stress-related disorder, substance misuse and psychotic disorders) on the risk of developing CKD were also evaluated using Cox regression model with age as underlying time scale adjusting for all above-mentioned covariates. A flexible nonparametric smoothing model was employed to illustrate the temporal pattern of the association between psychiatric disorders and following risk of CKD, using “bshazard” function in “bshazard” package (version 1.1) [44].

In subgroup analyses, we calculated the HRs by age at entry into the cohort (< 50, 50–60, or ≥ 60 years), age at exit from the cohort (≤ 70 or > 70), gender (female or male), follow up time (0–5, 5–10, 10–12, 12–13, or ≥ 13 years), the number of psychiatric disorders (1, 2, or ≥ 3) and genetic risk for CKD (in tertile of low, medium, high). The potential differential effects were tested using likelihood-ratio test comparing the models with and without the interaction terms (between the exposure of psychiatric disorders and above-mentioned variables including age at entry or exit from the cohort, gender, follow up time, the number of psychiatric disorders at baseline and genetic risk for CKD).

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis
sec.p: To further test the robustness of the results, we (1) removed CKD cases diagnosed within the first 1, 2, and 5 years after recruitment to further reduce the likelihood of reverse causality and calculated HRs, (2) excluding outliers of BMI (< 16.5 kg/m2 or > 40 kg/m2) [45] and calculated HRs, (3) the Fine and Gray competing risk model was used to estimate subdistribution hazard ratios using “crr” function in “cmprsk” package, considering all-cause death and CKD death (recorded as: cause of death of CKD, which was coded as “N18” in death registry) as the competing risk, respectively.

sec.title: Mediation analysis
sec.p: Considering that BMI, hypertension and diabetes are the potential risk factors for both CKD and psychiatric disorders, mediation analyses were individually conducted to decompose the total effect of psychiatry disorders on CKD that is mediated by BMI, hypertension and diabetes using the “mediate” function in the “mediation” package (version 4.5.0) [46]. Mediation analysis allowed for quantification of direct effects (the association of psychiatric disorders with CKD that is not mediated by these factors), indirect effect (the association of psychiatric disorders with CKD that is mediated by these factors) and total effect (direct and indirect effects).

Briefly, mediators of BMI (continuous), hypertension and diabetes (yes or no) were individually regressed on exposure (psychiatric disorders) and confounders (sex, ethnicity, Townsend deprivation index, physical activity, unprocessed meat intake, vegetable intake, processed meat intake, tea intake, CCI) using logistic or linear regression as appropriate. Subsequently, the outcome (CKD) was regressed on each mediator (BMI, hypertension or disbetes), exposure (psychiatric disorders), and above-mentioned confounders. No interaction was considered between exposure and mediators or between mediators and mediators. Point estimates and confidence intervals (CIs) were estimated using the quasi-Bayesian Monte Carlo approximation method, 95% CIs were obtained by bootstrap estimation with 1000 boots [46].

For analyzing the effect of any psychiatric disorders at baseline on risk of CKD, a 2-sided P-value < 0.05 was considered statistically significant. For 5 different psychiatric disorders of depression, anxiety, stress-related disorder, substance misuse and psychotic disorders, a P-value < Bonferroni multiple correction (0.05/5 = 0.01) was considered statistically significant. All analyses were conducted using R (version 4.1.2).

sec.title: Cohort characteristics
sec.p:
Among 441,893 UK Biobank participants enrolled in the current study, the median age was 57.97 years (median IQR: 50.32–63.47), 54.51% were females. We identified a total of 8,308 participants with psychiatric disorders at the baseline recruitment (including 3,932 for depression, 1,460 for anxiety, 328 for stress-related disorder, 3,309 for substance misuse and 613 for psychotic disorders, see in Additional File 1: Supplementary Table S5). As shown in Table 1, 3,029 (36.46%) patients with psychiatric disorder were under age 53, while the number in individuals without psychiatric disorders was 143,549 (33.11%). In general, compared with individuals without psychiatric disorders, patients with psychiatric disorder were more likely to be male, younger, obese, much more comorbidity, and have history of hypertension or diabetes (p < 0.001). Patients with psychiatric disorders also tended to have a lower level of education, annual household income and physical activity, as well as less consumptions of tea, vegetables and unprocessed meat and more processed meat intake (p < 0.001). With a median follow-up duration of 12.18 years, 17,287 cases (3.91%) of CKD were observed after 90 days from the baseline. Among patients with psychiatric disorders, 638 (7.68%) developed CKD, whereas the number of participants without psychiatric disorders who developed CKD was 16,649 (3.84%). Table 1

sec.title: The association between psychiatric disorders and CKD
sec.p: The proportional hazard (PH) assumption was firstly tested, as shown in Additional File 1: Supplementary Table S6, p-value for PH test for the association between psychiatric disorder and CKD was 0.002 in fully adjusted model, indicating a violation of the PH assumption. As depicted in Additional File 1: Supplementary Fig. 1A, the cumulative incidence curves for CKD crossed between the two groups of individuals with and without psychiatric disorders, further indicating a potential violation of the PH assumption. Consequently, a Cox regression model with age as the underlying time scale was employed, as shown in Additional File 1: Supplementary Fig. 1B, the two curves did not cross.

We observed that psychiatric disorders significantly associated with 52% higher risks for following CKD (95% CI: 1.40–1.65) in fully adjusted model (Fig. 2). For the subtype of 5 different psychiatric disorders at baseline separately, the highest HR was observed between stress-related disorder and CKD (HR = 1.95, 95% CI: 1.28–2.97, p-value = 0.002), and all the 5 separate psychiatric disorders at baseline significantly increased the risk of subsequent CKD (Fig. 2). To further illustrate the time-varying effects of psychiatric disorders on following CKD, a flexible nonparametric smoothing model was performed. We observed that the risk of developing CKD gradually increased after the diagnosis of psychiatric disorders (Fig. 3).Fig. 2
Associations between psychiatric disorders and CKD using Cox regression model with age as underlying time scale. Model 1 is not adjusted for any covariates. Model 2 is adjusted for sex. Model 3 is additionally adjusted for sociodemographic factors (ethnicity [in the primary analysis cohort only], Townsend deprivation index [in quantile], education level [college or university degree, A levels/ AS levels/ O levels/ GCSEs/ CSEs or equivalent, other degree, or unknown], annual household income [ultralow, low, medium, high, ultrahigh or unknown]), lifestyle (physical activity [low, moderate, high or unknown], vegetable intake [< 2, 2–3, 3–4, ≥ 4 servings per day or unknown], unprocessed meat intake [< 1, 1–2, > 2 times per week or unknown], processed meat intake [never, < 1, 1, ≥ 2 times per week or unknown] and tea intake [nondrinker, < 2, 2–3, or > 3 cups per day or unknown]), BMI (normal: < 25 kg/m2, overweight: 25–30 kg/m2, or obese: ≥ 30 kg/m2), hypertension and diabetes (yes or no), Charlson comorbidity index (0, 1–2, 3–4, ≥ 5). CI: Confidence interval; CKD: Chronic kidney diseaseFig. 3
Time-varying hazard ratio for incident CKD among patients with psychiatric disorders by time since baseline. Time-varying hazard ratios and 95% confidence intervals were derived from flexible nonparametric smoothing models. A ≤ 10 years after baseline. B > 10 years after baseline. All models were adjusted for sex, ethnicity [in the primary analysis cohort only], Townsend deprivation index [in quantile], education level [college or university degree, A levels/ AS levels/ O levels/ GCSEs/ CSEs or equivalent, other degree, or unknown], annual household income [ultralow, low, medium, high, ultrahigh or unknown]), lifestyle (physical activity [low, moderate, high or unknown], vegetable intake [< 2, 2–3, 3–4, ≥ 4 servings per day or unknown], unprocessed meat intake [< 1, 1–2, > 2 times per week or unknown], processed meat intake [never, < 1, 1, ≥ 2 times per week or unknown] and tea intake [nondrinker, < 2, 2–3, or > 3 cups per day or unknown]), BMI (normal: < 25 kg/m2, overweight: 25–30 kg/m2, or obese: ≥ 30 kg/m.2), hypertension and diabetes (yes or no), Charlson comorbidity index (0, 1–2, 3–4, ≥ 5)

Subsequently, 297,787 participants were included in the genetic cohort. As shown in Additional File 1: Supplementary Table S7, 5,473 patients with psychiatric disorders were identified. Similarly, 1,861 (34.00%) of the psychiatric patients were under 53, while the number of individuals without psychiatric disorders was 90,307 (30.89%) in the genetic cohort. As shown in Additional File 1: Supplementary Table S8, in the genetic cohort, we identified 2,619 individuals with depression, 995 individuals with anxiety, 217 patients with stress-related disorder, 2,173 patients with substance misuse and 334 individuals with psychotic disorder. When taking genetic susceptibility to CKD into consideration, psychiatric disorders increased risks for following CKD with HR at 1.49 (95% CI: 1.35–1.65, p-value < 0.001) (Additional File 1: Supplementary Table S9).The HR for the association between stress-related disorders and CKD became 1.86 (95%CI: 1.14–3.04, p-value = 0.013), and for psychotic disorders and CKD, it was 1.66 (95%CI: 1.06–2.60, p-value = 0.028). Although these associations were nominally significant, they did not reach statistical significance after applying the Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons (threshold at 0.05/5 = 0.01). The lack of significance may be due to the small sample sizes. Specifically, only 217 patients were identified with stress-related disorders and 334 with psychotic disorders at baseline. Among these, a mere 16 patients with stress-related disorders and 19 with psychotic disorders developed CKD during the follow up.

sec.title: Subgroup analyses
sec.p:
In subgroup analyses, we observed significant differential effects of follow-up time, age at entry or exit the cohort, and the number of psychiatric disorders at baseline on the association between psychiatric disorders and CKD (P for interaction < 0.05, Table 2). The correlations between psychiatric disorders and CKD were significant in both females and males, but no interaction was observed (female: HR = 1.51, 95% CI: 1.35–1.68, p-value < 0.001; male: HR = 1.54, 95% CI: 1.36–1.74, p-value < 0.001; P for interaction = 0.205). When stratified by genetic susceptibility to CKD, psychiatric disorders increased subsequent risk of CKD in all subgroups with no interaction effects. Iindividuals with medium or high genetic susceptibility had higher HRs (medium genetic risk: HR = 1.61, 95% CI:1.35–1.90, p-value < 0.001; high genetic risk: HR = 1.53, 95% CI: 1.30–1.80, p-value < 0.001; P for interaction = 0.830). Interestingly, the increased risk for subsequent CKD was only observed in individuals followed up for more than 10 years (10–12 years: HR = 1.60, 95% CI: 1.34–1.91, p-value < 0.001; 12–13 years: HR = 1.66, 95% CI: 1.29–2.13, p-value < 0.001; ≥ 13 years: HR = 1.52, 95% CI: 1.13–2.04, p-value = 0.005; P for interaction < 0.001). Individuals with more than 3 subtypes of psychiatric disorders at baseline had a higher risk of CKD (number = 1: HR = 1.46, 95% CI: 1.34–1.60, p-value < 0.001; number = 2: HR = 1.82, 95% CI: 1.46–2.28, p-value < 0.001; number ≥ 3: HR = 2.96, 95% CI: 1.81–4.83, p-value < 0.001; P for interaction < 0.001). In addition, the association was much higher among individuals with older age exit from the cohort (age ≤ 70: HR = 1.22, 95% CI: 1.10–1.37, p-value < 0.001; age > 70: HR = 1.32, 95% CI: 1.17–1.49, p-value < 0.001; P for interaction = 0.038) (Table 2).

In sensitivity analyses, results were unchanged after excluding participants diagnosed with CKD within 1, 2, and 5 years (Additional File 1: Supplementary Figure S2, S3 and S4). When further excluding individuals with BMI < 16.5 kg/m2 or > 40 kg/m2, the results were not significantly changed (Additional File 1: Supplementary Figure S5). As shown in Additional File 1: Supplementary Table S10, when all-cause and CKD death were considered as a competing risk, psychiatric disorders still significantly increased the risk of CKD.

sec.title: Mediation analyses
sec.p:
Mediation analyses showed that BMI and hypertension mediated some proportion of the association between psychiatry disorders and CKD (Supplementary Table S11 and Fig. 4). Hypertension turned out to be the most prominent mediator, which mediated 49.13% (95% CI: 37.60% to 67.08%) of the total effect. We also observed significant mediating effects for BMI and diabetes, which mediated 12.11% (95% CI: 8.49% to 17.24%) and 3.78% (95% CI: 1.58%−6.52%) of the total effects.Fig. 4
Path diagram of the significant mediators of BMI and hypertension on the association between psychiatric disorders and CKD. A Mediating role of BMI. B Mediating role of hypertension

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: By using a large-scale community-based cohort in the UK with more than 500,000 participants, we observed that psychiatric disorders increased the risk of subsequent CKD. Specifically, patients who are under the age of 60, have multiple psychiatric morbidities, or have been diagnosed with psychiatric disorders for over 10 years are at higher risk of developing CKD. BMI and hypertension might be the mediators involved in the positive association between psychiatric disorders and CKD. Our findings add evidence of the relationship between psychiatric disorders and subsequent CKD.

The major strength in our study is the identification of delayed onset of increased risk for CKD in patients with psychiatric disorders. Only patients who had been diagnosed with psychiatric disorders for over 10 years exhibited an elevated risk of developing CKD. By employing a flexible nonparametric smoothing model, we observed a tendency for the hazard ratio to increase among patients with psychiatric disorders, and became significant after about 3000 days (10 years) follow-ups. In subgroup analysis, we observed a higher risk for CKD among psychiatric patients who entered the cohort at an age of less than 60 and exited the cohort at an age greater than 70, which also suggests that the effects of psychiatric disorders on the risk of CKD may persist over a prolonged period. Young people are more susceptible to both mental illnesses [47] and CKD [48, 49], which could potentially explain the higher incidence of psychiatric disorders and higher risk for developing CKD among psychiatric patients who aged under 60 at baseline. For patients exit the cohort aged greater than 70, the higher risk for CKD might result from the age-related structure and function changes of kidney as well as decline in renal function [50]. The possible reasons accounted for the delayed onset of increased risk for CKD included cumulative physiological stress, or chronic inflammatory response. Specifically, cumulative exposure to psychiatric disorder will lead to dysregulation of physiological stress system (e.g., the hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal axis) [51], further resulting in cellular aging and chronic inflammatory response [52, 53]. The chronic inflammatory response will accumulate neutrophils and macrophages, resulting in inflammatory injury and kidney fibrosis, followed by CKD progression [54]. Our recent study has provided evidence that inflammatory response (like interleukin 1 receptor and cytokine receptor activities) were important factors mediating the association between the patterns of exposure to adverse life events and the risk of subsequent CKD [33]. In addition, the low awareness of early CKD and delayed detection of the disease [55] may also partly explain the delayed onset of increased risk for CKD in patients with psychiatric disorders.

We observed that hypertension, BMI and diabetes, common risk factors for CKD, are significant mediators in the relationship between psychiatric disorders and CKD. Among these, hypertension turned out to be the most prominent mediator mediating 49.13% of the total effect. The mediating roles of hypertension observed in our study are consistent with many previous studies reporting the increased risk for subsequent adverse cardiovascular events in patients with various psychiatric disorders [13, 14]. Stress-related disorders associated with early onset of cardiovascular disease, exhibiting higher hazard ratio within the first year after diagnosis [14]. The mediating role of hypertension is quite complex, as it is not only a strong determinant of worse kidney and cardiovascular outcomes but also a consequence of decreased kidney function where renal function decline aggravates hypertension [56]. Diabetes, another key mediator, has also been widely reported to be associated with psychiatric disorder [57, 58]. Diabetes is a common risk factor for CKD, has been reported to be associated with glomerular hyperfiltration and total GFR increase [6]. Obesity is known to induce a chronic low-grade inflammatory state and release adipokines that can directly impair kidney function [59]. Depression and anxiety have been reported to be associated with obesity [60], with secretion of adipokines, including glomerular hyperfiltration [61]. However, obesity, hypertension and diabetes themselves may interact with each other [62, 63], making the mediating roles more complicated. For example, obesity and hypertension are important drivers of microvascular dysfunction in type 2 diabetes, which are associated with several brain diseases and depression [64]. Therefore, the intricate relationships among obesity, hypertension, and diabetes that influence the association between psychiatric disorders and chronic kidney disease (CKD) necessitate further exploration, and the underlying molecular mechanisms involved are eagerly awaited to be unraveled. Furthermore, it has been reported that the progression of CKD might worsen psychiatric symptoms [65], potentially creating a bidirectional relationship between psychiatric disorders and CKD that still requires deeper investigation in the future.

Our findings in line with previous studies reported the significant positive association between psychiatric disorders, including depression [66, 67], anxiety [68], substance misuse [69], psychotic disorder [70] or stress-related disorders [14] and a rapid decline in kidney function or risk for developing CKD. However, few studies focused on the time-varying effects of psychiatric disorders on the subsequent risk of CKD. In our study, the strongest association was observed between stress-related disorders and chronic kidney disease (CKD). However, after further adjusting genetic risk for CKD and applying the Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons, this association did not reach statistical significance which may be attributed to the limited sample size. Similarly, the association between psychotic disorders and CKD did not pass Bonferroni correction either, after further considering genetic susceptibility to CKD. As more data become available, it will be important to further explore the relationship between psychiatric disorders and CKD considering genetic susceptibility.

The findings revealed by subgroup analyses can facilitate more effective screening and preventive strategies in specific populations with higher risks, such as psychiatric patients under the age of 60, individuals with multiple psychiatric morbidities, or those who have been diagnosed with psychiatric disorders for over 10 years. Our research also provided evidence that lifestyle interventions (for example losing weight, healthy diet or physical exercise) targeting mediators of BMI, hypertension, and diabetes, together with routine monitoring of kidney function as well as early screening and diagnosis of CKD, may be potential strategies for preventing the progression to CKD in patients with psychiatric disorders, especially the psychiatric populations with higher risks. Furthermore, the tailored management of hypertension, diabetes and obesity, as well as the implementation of integrated psychiatric and renal care models, are also possible strategies to prevent CKD progression in these populations.

There are also some limitations to be pointed out. Firstly, this study is mainly composed of individuals with a median age of 57.97 years, making it difficult to extrapolate our results to, for example, younger patients aged 20–40 years. Secondly, the exclusion of non-Caucasian participants in the genetic cohort may limit the generalizability of our findings to other populations. Also, a “healthy volunteer” selection bias regarding UK Biobank has been identified. Thirdly, some potential residual confounders that are difficult to detect were not included in our study. In addition, some confounders such as BMI, diet, education and income levels used in our study were based on the measured at the baseline survey, the potential measurement error might exist, this may lead to bias in the analysis. Fifthly, because this study mainly focused on patients who received a clinical diagnosis of psychiatric disorders through hospitalization with reliance on inpatient records, participants with mild or subclinical psychiatric symptoms that were managed in primary care or remained undiagnosed were not included in our study. This exclusion may have led to an underestimation of the number of psychiatric disorder cases and limited the generalizability of the study to individuals with milder psychiatric symptoms. Further research focusing on the association between milder psychiatric disorders and the risk of subsequent CKD will be a promising direction in the future. In addition, due to the low awareness of early CKD and the influence of healthcare-seeking behavior, newly developed cases of incident CKD may also be underdiagnosed. Finally, the delayed onset of increased risk for CKD was observed after 10 years of follow-up might partly result from the delayed detection of CKD, which may bias the observation.

In conclusion, psychiatric disorders were found to be associated with a delayed onset of enhanced risk for subsequent CKD. Patients with psychiatric conditions who are under the age of 60, with multiple psychiatric morbidities or having been diagnosed with psychiatric disorders for over 10 years may be high-risk populations. Additionally, BMI, hypertension, and diabetes emerged as potential mediators involved in the relationship between psychiatric disorders and CKD. Our study highlights the significance of lifestyle interventions, routine monitoring of kidney function, early screening for CKD, and personalized management strategies for psychiatric patients as potential approaches to the precise prevention of CKD.
